conclusion: Let the square lie in the y–z plane (the plane of the paper).
The axis OO′ is the z-axis (vertical, in the plane of the coil).
Side ab is parallel to the z-axis and situated at y = –L⁄4; side cd is parallel to the z-axis at y = –L⁄4 + L = 3L⁄4.
The uniform magnetic field B is along the +y direction (→).
A rigid body that rotates with constant angular speed ω about the z-axis has, at position vector r, a linear velocity v = ω k × r.

premise: For any point of the coil, r = (0, y, 0); hence v = ω k × r.
conclusion: v = –ωy i (directed perpendicular to the page).
The motional electric field in a conductor is E = v × B.

premise: With v = –ωy i and B = +B j, E = v × B.

conclusion: Only the two vertical sides (ab and cd) contribute, because on the horizontal sides dl is along y while E is along z (E·dl = 0 there).

premise: Side ab (y = –L⁄4, length L, dl along +z): ε_ab = ∫ E·dl = (ωB|y|)L.
Side cd (y = 3L⁄4, length L, dl along –z, E along –z): ε_cd = (ωB|y|)L.
The result is independent of time (the same magnitude and polarity at every instant), so the instantaneous emf is constant.
conclusion: ε_rms = ε_peak = N ω B L².
